content.question:
"Aeole (namque tibi divum pater atque hominum rex

et mulcere dedit fluctus et tollere vento),

gens inimica mihi Tyrrhenum navigat aequor

Ilium in Italiam portans victosque penates:

5incute vim ventis submersasque obrue puppes,

aut age diversos et disice corpora ponto.

Sunt mihi bis septem praestanti corpore Nymphae,

quarum quae forma pulcherrima Deiopea,

conubio iungam stabili propriamque dicabo."

Aeneid 1. 65-73

Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question.

1. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in lines 1-2 (Aeole . . . vento) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it.

2. In lines 1-4 (Aeole . . . penates), which four Latin words identify the source of Aeolus’ power?

3. In lines 1-4 (Aeole . . . penates), which two Latin words are joined by -que (line 4) ?

4. (A) Identify one participle in this passage and (B) translate it in context.

5. In lines 3-6 (gens . . . ponto), which three Latin words can be translated “strengthen the winds!”?

6. In lines 7-9 (Sunt . . . dicabo), (A) identify the one dative of possession and (B) translate it in context.

7. In lines 7-9 (Sunt . . . dicabo), which two Latin words indicate the level of physical attractiveness of the fourteen nymphs?

8. (A) Identify one ablative of means in this passage and (B) translate it in context.

9. Briefly explain why, for the Romans, it would be important that Aeneas bring the penates from Troy to Italy. Answer in 1-2 complete sentences.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
